title: Karuvarakundu
text:
Karuvarakundu is a semi-urban area in the eastern part of <a href="Malappuram%20district">Malappuram district</a>, <a href="Kerala">Kerala</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. It is situated east of <a href="Manjeri">Manjeri</a>, northeast of <a href="Perinthalmanna">Perinthalmanna</a> and 30 km southeast of <a href="Nilambur">Nilambur</a>. The Olippuzha River, a tributary of the <a href="Kadalundi%20River">Kadalundipuzha</a>, flows through the town. Karuvarakundu is close to the <a href="Western%20Ghats">Western Ghats</a> and hence prone to <a href="landslide">landslide</a>s. The <a href="Silent%20Valley%20National%20Park">Silent Valley National Park</a> was included in Karuvarakundu until 1990's.
The name "Karuvarakundu" means "place of the <a href="blacksmith">blacksmith</a>", indicating the town's history as a metalworking centre. It is known as the <a href="Jamshedpur">Jamshedpur</a> of south India because of its range of metal depositories.
There are many <a href="tea">tea</a> and <a href="rubber">rubber</a> <a href="plantation">plantation</a>s in and around Karuvarakundu. The town is an educational centre of eastern <a href="Eranad">Eranad</a>, with a total of 20 schools and 5 colleges.
Karuvarakundu is part of the setting of the novel <a href="Arabi%20Ponnu">Arabi Ponnu</a>, by <a href="M.%20T.%20Vasudevan%20Nair">M. T. Vasudevan Nair</a> and <a href="N.%20P.%20Mohammed">N. P. Mohammed</a>.
History.
"Karu" means <a href="iron">iron</a> ore. The place where iron ore was excavated came to be known as Karu varum kundu, later shortened to Karuvarakundu. <a href="Sword">Sword</a>s and utensils made of <a href="iron">iron</a> were made here two thousand years ago, and exported to countries like <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, and <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>. The people engaged in iron <a href="ore">ore</a> mining took the <a href="family">family</a> name Aripanikkar. Karuvarakundu is known as the <a href="Jamshedpur">Jamshedpur</a> of <a href="south">south</a> <a href="India">India</a> because of its extensive mining history.
The <a href="Malabar%20rebellion">Malabar rebellion</a> of 1921 led to riots in Karuvarakundu. On 20 August 1921 the news that the <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> had fired at a mosque in <a href="Tirurangadi">Tirurangadi</a> spread in Karuvarakundu, and protests against the <a href="British%20people">British</a> began. On the next day, a mob attacked the police station and seized weapons, leaving the <a href="police%20station">police station</a> and the <a href="tourist">tourist</a> <a href="Bungalow">Bungalow</a> on fire. The <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> <a href="army">army</a> subsequently came to Karuvarakundu to suppress the rioters. The army barracks were first situated at Chembankunnu and later moved to Cambinkunnu, the current location of the Karuvarakundu Government Higher Secondary School.
Geography.
Karuvarakundu is located on a sloping region near a forest. The mountains of the <a href="Western%20Ghats">Western Ghats</a>, which reach a height of 1250 <a href="metre">metre</a>s above sea level, are located in the southeast of the Karuvarakundu <a href="Panchayath">Panchayath</a>. The Olippuzha river, the longest river flowing through Karuvarakundu, originates in these mountains. The river Kallanpuzha, which also flows through Karuvarakundu, originates at a height of 1050m.
The Karuvarakundu Panchayath covers an area 64.2 km2 and is part of the <a href="Nilambur">Nilambur</a> subdivision of the <a href="Malappuram">Malappuram</a> district. It is one of the main <a href="agricultural">agricultural</a> areas of the <a href="Malappuram">Malappuram</a> district. It includes <a href="Kerala%20Estate">Kerala Estate</a>, and shares borders with <a href="Amarambalam">Amarambalam</a> and <a href="Puthur%20%28Palakkad%29">Puthur (Palakkad)</a> in the north, Puthur Panchayath in the east, <a href="Alanallur">Alanallur</a> in the south and <a href="Kalikavu">Kalikavu</a>, <a href="Tuvvur">Tuvvur</a>, and <a href="Chokkad">Chokkad</a> in the west.
Transportation.
Karuvarakundu village is connected via road to the nearest towns, including <a href="Manjeri">Manjeri</a>, <a href="Perinthalmanna">Perinthalmanna</a> and <a href="Nilambur">Nilambur</a>. State Highway 39 (SH 39) between Perumbilavu and Nilambur passes through Karuvarakundu. It is also connected to National Highway No. 966, which connects <a href="Palakkad">Palakkad</a> and <a href="Coimbatore">Coimbatore</a>. The nearest airport is at <a href="Kozhikode%20Airport">Karipur</a>. The nearest railway stations are at <a href="Tuvvur">Tuvvur</a> and <a href="Melattur%2C%20Kerala">Melattur</a>.
